Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a high performance liquid chromatograph for the enhancement of biogeochemical education and research of trace element speciation in environmental systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
1029246
Johannesson

This award provides funding for a high performance liquid chromatograph for biogeoechmical and trace element research and training. The HPLC will be coupled with an existing NSF-funded magnetic sector ICP-MS for high-resolution elemental measurements. The main research use will be for assessing trace element concentrations and speciation in natural waters in order to understand biogeochemical transformations. The oxidation-reduction state will be able to be inferred from the speciation distribution in environmental samples. A principal research theme will address inorganic-organic interactions through ligand complexes. The PIs arsenic geochemistry studies in groundwater will immediately benefit. Researchers in the School of Science and Engineering, the School of Medicine, and the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine will be engaged in sharing the instrumentation. Xavier University of Louisiana, a historically African American university, has scientists who routinely use Tulane?s coordinated instrumentation facility (CIF). They will given access to the new instrumentation. The acquisition will play an important role in encouraging the participation of under-represented groups in the areas of science and engineering through such programs as the Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation in Research Program, as well as through the PI?s outreach to women in sciences through the Newcomb College Institute. The will be incorporated into environmental geochemistry coursework ? including an outreach component investigating local water quality issues. The instrument will be incorporated into the CIF. A full-time staff scientist maintains the laboratory. The staff scientist will provide routine instrument service and maintenance. Per hour cost structure for CIF resources (HR-ICP-MS) will be used initially for cost-recovery. Instrument time will be scheduled according to CIF policy. The PI and staff scientist will train new users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The chief intellectual merit of new HPLC is its potential to greatly enhance research concerning trace element biogeochemistry by providing the means to quantify the chemical speciation as well as total concentrations of a number of trace elements in natural waters and other environmental samples. Chemical speciation refers to the form in which a trace element occurs in environments like natural waters, and includes among a number of possibilities, the oxidation-reduction states and aqueous complexes with inorganic and organic ligands. The PI’s expects that her NSF funded studies of arsenic and tungsten geochemistry in groundwater flow systems to be among the first projects to benefit.

 

In addition to enabling the research of the PI and her graduate students, the new HPLC instrument is an invaluable addition to researchers in the School of Science and Engineering, the School of Medicine, and the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at Tulane University. Furthermore, researchers at Xavier University of Louisiana, a historically African American university, who routinely use Tulane’s Coordinated Instrumentation Facility (CIF), should benefit from the acquisition of the HPLC as will researchers at other universities in the region. The HPLC has already helped to attract participation of under-represented groups in the areas of science and engineering through the Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation in Research Program (LAMP; http://www.tulane.edu/~lamp/home.html), as well as through the PI’s outreach to women in sciences through the Newcomb College Institute (http://newcomb.tulane.edu/). In the near future, the HPLC is expected to assist in supporting the public service learning component of the PI’s Environmental Geochemistry class (EENS-636), which will directly involve undergraduate and graduate students enrolled in the class partnering with the New Orleans community to investigate and solve local water quality issues.

 

The principal activities to date have involved purchasing and setting up the HPLC. This has been accomplished with the assistance of professional staff at Tulane's CIF. We are currently optimizing the HPLC to allow for on-line separation of arsenic and selenium species. One of my PhD students has expressed interest in arsenic and selenium speciation analysis of groundwaters discharging to the Gulf of Mexico. We are considering also optimizing the instrument to separate and analyze tellurium species in natural waters. Tellurium is expected to have a broadly similar chemistry to selenium, however, very little appears to be known about tellurium in non-mineralized, low-temperature natural waters.

 

The most exciting outreach activity that I am involved with is bringing my environmental geochemistry class into Tulane University's service learning component, and particularly, developing ties with members of the local community. These ties with the community revolve around the local desire to restore the former cypress swamp of the Bayou Bienvenue BB) located proximal to the Lower 9th Ward and Holy Cross neighborhoods of New Orleans and Saint Bernard parish. We will be presenting some of our preliminary work on REEs in BB waters at this fall's AGU meeting in San Francisco. In addition, new undergraduate geology major at Tulane will begin working with us in BB this semester. This comes to this and my other projects through the Louisiana Alliance for Minority Participation at Tulane University (http://www.tulane.edu/~lamp/conferences_and_recruitment.html). We hope to employ the HPLC in our continuing investigations of BB in the service-learning component of my environmental geochemistry class.
